title: On Telegram, Russian messengers of war
summary: Since Russia's invasion of Ukraine, the number of channels run by Russian 'war correspondents' has soared into the thousands on Telegram. These new propagandists assist in radicalizing the 'special military operation' initiated by Vladimir Putin.

title: Putin says he's open to peace deals, but only 'based on the realities on the ground' in Russian-occupied territories of Ukraine
summary: The Kremlin leader spoke at the end of the BRICS summit in the city of Kazan, where he faced calls from some of Russia's most important allies for the fighting in Ukraine to end. Putin also held talks with United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres in the pair's first meeting since April 2022.

title: Silence from the ICC judges hearing the Netanyahu case
summary: Issued by the prosecutor five months ago, the judges of the International Criminal Court are due to rule on the request for an arrest warrant against the Israeli prime minister.

title: Gisèle Pelicot, invincible even against 'lowest depths of the human soul'
summary: 'I'm not expressing anger or hatred. I'm expressing my determination to change this society,' the former wife of Dominique Pelicot, repeatedly sedated by her husband so he and dozens of men could rape her, told the court on Wednesday.

title: LA prosecutor says will ask for resentencing of Menendez brothers over parents' killing
summary: Los Angeles County District Attorney George Gascón announced a decision on Thursday in the case of brothers Erik and Lyle Menendez, who have spent 34 years in prison for the shotgun murder of their parents.

title: 'I'm not coming with the same charisma as Hervé Renard': Laurent Bonadei, the little-known coach who whispers in the ear of football's Bleues
summary: The 54-year-old former assistant coach, who coached youth teams for 16 years, is making his debut as No.1 with the French women's team against Jamaica in Sochaux on Friday.

title: Israel and Hamas signal openness on talks to end Gaza war
summary: After a meeting in Cairo, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said he welcomed Egypt's readiness to reach a deal 'for the release of the hostages' still held by militants in Gaza, then directed the head of Israel's Mossad spy agency to leave for key mediator Qatar on Sunday to 'advance a series of initiatives,' a statement from his office said.

title: Lebanon's ancient city of Baalbek bears the scars of Israeli bombs
summary: Strikes have killed 50 people in the city known both for its Roman temples and as a Hezbollah stronghold.

title: French conference on aid to Lebanon raises $1 billion in pledges
summary: Representatives from 70 countries and organizations gathered in Paris on Thursday to pledge $800 million in humanitarian aid and $200 million for Lebanon's security forces.

title: Environmental activist fined for deflating SUV tires in Paris
summary: Maxime D. would insert lentils into the tire valves of these vehicles to call out the pollution they cause. He was fined €300.

title: Paul Watson, speaking from his Greenland prison: 'I want France to be our home'
summary: The defender of the oceans is still in detention in Greenland pending a decision on his extradition to Japan, the Nuuk court ruled on Wednesday. In France, mobilization is growing in support of the activist.

title: Climate: Greenhouse gas emissions are too high, pushing planet toward +3.1°C warming
summary: Greenhouse gas emissions are still too high to limit the rise in global temperatures below the thresholds set by the Paris Agreement, warns the United Nations Environment Program, two weeks ahead of COP29 in Baku, Azerbaijan.

title: Macron and the dangers of 'bluster' diplomacy
summary: Despite the many setbacks he has encountered, the French president claims to still play a key role in what he considers to be his 'reserved domain:' the international stage.

title: Pro-Palestinian protests lose steam on American campuses
summary: As elsewhere in the country, students and faculty at the University of Missouri were disciplined following the spring protests. Despite criticizing the Biden administration's Middle East policy, Democratic activists may still decide to vote for Kamala Harris.

title: Western officials confirm North Korean troops have been deployed in Russia
summary: NATO and Washington said they have proof of the dispatch of North Korean troops to Russia, announced a few days ago by Seoul and Kyiv. They have not confirmed whether these soldiers are expected to go fight in Ukraine.

title: French government orders displaced Ukrainians to give up subsidized accommodation
summary: In the Grand-Est region, Ukrainians who have fled the war are receiving letters asking them to leave their homes, on the grounds that they have not integrated. This measure has provoked anger in Ukrainian groups.

title: Trump likened to a 'fascist' by General John Kelly, his former chief of staff
summary: 'He certainly prefers the dictator approach to government,' said Kelly, confirming the White House candidate's fascination with Hitler. 'This is a window into who Donald Trump really is,' commented his Democratic rival, Kamala Harris.

title: Insect population collapse is grossly underestimated by high-profile work
summary: Two researchers identified methodological and statistical errors in the largest database on global changes in invertebrate populations, cited in more than 1,000 subsequent studies.

title: Channel crossings: Mayors of small French coastal towns express helplessness
summary: As long as migrant gatherings and attempts to reach the UK were confined to Calais and the Channel Tunnel, officials in French coastal towns did not have to deal with this harsh reality. But small boat crossings have put them on the front line.

title: Harris joined by Bruce Springsteen and Obama in star-studded swing state rally
summary: The 'Born in the USA' singer, known for his socially conscious, working-class anthems, performed three songs, including 'The Promised Land,' 'Land of Hope and Dreams' and 'Dancing in the Dark' as part of a cameo designed to bolster Harris's blue-collar credentials.

title: 'Paris Games Week' 2024: Five things to do at the Paris video game show
summary: France's biggest video game trade show opened its doors at the Porte de Versailles exhibition center in Paris on Wednesday, October 23 and will close them again on Sunday.

title: 54 people have died crossing the Channel in 2024. Are the rescue operations adequate?
summary: Since the beginning of the year, 54 people have died at sea trying to reach England. Casualties are occurring increasingly close to the coast. Despite a reinforced stronger search and rescue system, the fatality rate is rising.

title: Bob Dylan delights Paris with his 'Rough and Rowdy Ways'
summary: The American musician and his band, on a European tour until November 14, were at the La Seine Musicale concert venue, on Thursday, October 24, for the first of two sold-out concerts at the Paris suburban venue.

title: In southern Lebanon, UN peacekeepers are caught in a vice
summary: The international soldiers in the UN peacekeeping force are trapped between the Israeli army, which sees them as a nuisance, and Hezbollah, which seeks to exploit them.

title: Luxury goods: Salvo of poor quarterly results confirms storm warnings
summary: The publication of third quarter sales for LVMH, Kering and L'Oréal reveals just how difficult the global luxury goods market is becoming. Of the sector's giants, only Hermès is still enjoying strong sales growth.

title: Trump against the fascism accusation
summary: With less than two weeks to go before the election, former aides to the Republican presidential candidate are issuing warnings about his authoritarian tendencies – accusations that must be taken seriously.

title: North Korean troops at Russia's side illustrate Pyongyang's new global ambitions
summary: At a time when North Korea has made South Korea its main enemy, Pyongyang and Moscow have promised mutual assistance 'in the event of aggression.'

title: French retailer Auchan close to selling its stores in Russia
summary: According to French online news outlet La Lettre, Auchan is negotiating the sale of its 230 outlets to a local operative. The name of Gazprombank, which had already acquired shopping centers belonging to Ikea, has been put forward.

title: Lebanon calls Israeli strike that killed three journalists a 'war crime'
summary: The 'deliberate' strike 'targeting journalists' in the south of the country on Friday was, according to Prime Minister Najib Mikati, among the 'war crimes committed by the Israeli enemy.'

title: US election betting online: 'Some consider the data to be real-time polls'
summary: On the popular platform Polymarket, most punters bet on Donald Trump: One Frenchman even bet $45 million. The craze is symptomatic of the fragility of American democracy, writes journalist Philippe Escande.

title: French businessman Hugues Mulliez receives six-year suspended prison sentence after fatal accident in Greece
summary: In 2019, the French businessman was piloting a speedboat when it collided with a fishing boat. Two men died and a woman was seriously injured.

title: French league upholds ruling that PSG owes Mbappé €55 million in unpaid wages
summary: Kylian Mbappé says the club owes him three months' salary and the last third of a loyalty bonus, while PSG has argued there was a verbal agreement for him to relinquish them.

title: Kremlin denies report of Musk-Putin secret talks
summary: The WSJ report claimed Putin had discussed personal and political matters with the world's richest man, who has supported Donald Trump's election campaign with donations and messages on his X platform.

title: Russia hikes interest rates to 21%, highest since 2003
summary: The rise takes rates above an emergency level introduced in February 2022 – just after Moscow ordered troops into Ukraine – and to their highest since 2003 as the regulator battles to stem the economic fallout of the conflict.

title: French courts set to try far-right activists for murder of Argentine rugby star
summary: Former international rugby union player Federico Martin Aramburu, 42, was shot dead in Paris on March 19, 2022. French magistrates have ordered trials for two far-right activist suspects, as well as their accomplices.

title: UN rights chief warns of war's 'darkest moment' unfolding in Northern Gaza
summary: Volker Türk warned that Israel's ongoing military actions could amount to 'atrocity crimes and pointed out that 'more than 150,000 people are reported dead, wounded or missing in Gaza.'

title: 'In a fractured America, it takes real courage for artists to openly support Harris or Trump'
summary: Unlike the 2016 presidential election, when the cultural world fiercely opposed Trump, singers and actors are now showing more restraint in their support for the vice president, observes Le Monde columnist Michel Guerrin.

title: French policeman to face trial over 'Yellow Vest' protester's lost eye
summary: A French judge has ruled on a 2019 case, in which protestor Manuel Coisne lost an eye to a tear gas grenade, shot by a policeman during a 'Yellow Vest' protest, ordering the policeman's trial to go ahead.

title: Almost 50 years apart, two French trials symbolize the long conceptual battle on rape
summary: The trial of dozens of men accused of raping Gisèle Pelicot while she was drugged has shed light on the significance and relevance of ideas generated over the last 50 years by feminist thinkers and gender studies in France.

title: Seven people charged with cyberbullying Paris Olympics ceremony director
summary: French authorities have charged the individuals, aged 22 to 79, with cyberbullying and issuing death threats against Thomas Jolly after backlash over his bold performances.

title: Israel targets the few remaining journalists in northern Gaza
summary: The Israeli army has accused six Palestinian reporters from Al-Jazeera, who are covering the intense violence of the current offensive in the region, of being Hamas and Islamic Jihad fighters.

title: French PM presents report preparing for dramatic climate warming scenario
summary: Temperatures in mainland France are on track to increase by 4°C by 2100 due to global warming, the government warned Friday, urging coping strategies for a much hotter country.

title: Cinemed festival in Montpellier echoes Middle East's conflicts
summary: Of the 11 Lebanese, Palestinian and Israeli films selected for this year's event, only a handful manage to distance themselves from legitimate suffering, in favor of a more subtle approach.

title: Guadeloupe suffers power outage blamed on striking staff
summary: Authorities blamed striking workers for the outage in the French overseas territory. Restored electricity supply for the 230,000 affected households was expected at 3 pm local time at best.

title: Gaza ministry says Israeli forces detain hundreds at hospital
summary: The Israeli army said it and Israeli Security Agency forces 'are operating in the area of the Kamal Adwan Hospital in Jabalia, based on intelligence information regarding the presence of terrorists and terrorist infrastructure.'

title: Kendall Jenner, a model of influence
summary: With nearly 300 million followers on Instagram, she's more a star than a model, beyond mere online influence. She undergoes metamorphoses, alternating naturalness and elegance, sophistication and sensuality.

title: 75 sickened as McDonald's severe E. Coli outbreak expands
summary: The number of hospitalizations has risen to 22, though no additional deaths have been reported beyond that of an elderly patient in Colorado according to the FDA and CDC.

title: 'Washington Post' announces will not endorse Harris or Trump in US election
summary: CEO William Lewis said this was a return 'to our roots of not endorsing presidential candidates.'

title: Biden apologizes for Native American boarding school atrocities
summary: From the early 1800s until the 1970s, the United States ran hundreds of Indian boarding schools across the country to forcibly assimilate Native children into European settler culture, including conversion to Christianity.

title: Phil Lesh, co-founder of the Grateful Dead, dies at 84
summary: The bassist and pioneering musician co-wrote some of the Dead's most notable, jam-worthy tracks – 'Dark Star' and 'St. Stephen' among them – and also sang harmonies for the band.

title: Moody's cuts France outlook, opening door to credit downgrade
summary: France's new finance minister Antoine Armand noted the decision Friday but maintained that the country is able to carry out 'far-reaching reforms,' adding that France has economic strength and vowed to restore its finances

title: In the country of Georgia, the government campaigns 'for peace'
summary: In the run-up to the October 26 parliamentary elections, the Georgian Dream party is using the war in Ukraine as a deterrent.

title: In Brazil, fires and the destruction of nature inspire artists
summary: Galleries and museums are displaying works that depict climate change and its brutality for ecosystems. For the artists, they are a way of sounding the alarm.
